Kato Clever and the
 big trouble 
 
 Herminder Ohri
 English 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 In a smal garden in the city, there was a 
 
 big tre. Many smal animals lived 
 together on the big tre. 
 There also lived a family of squirels. 
 
 Viki was one litle squirel among them 
 who liked to talk big. His cousin, Kato 
 
 from Far Forest had come to visit him. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 One evening, as al the animals who lived
 
 in the litle garden were just going to
 slep, they heard loud sounds from the
 park, next to the litle garden.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 2  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Kato and the other squirels saw big 
 yelow machines, and men in hard yelow 
 
 hats, pointing to the litle garden and 
 other houses on the stret. 
 They were going to pul them al down 
 
 and build a parking lot. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 3  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The people who lived there would move
 
 to other houses. No one gave a thought
 to the animals, birds and insects who
 lived in the litle garden. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 4  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The machines were first spoted by the 
 mole family. To be more exact, by Mister 
 Poples, the eldest who told Master 
 
 Moples, who in turn told the youngest, 
 Litle Poples. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 5  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 When they were young they were caled
 Pop, Mop and Pip. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 6  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Mister Poples told the squirels, the squirels told the birds, caterpilars,
 buterflies, tiny spiders and al those who lived in the litle garden.
 
 
 There was total panic, a lot of runing, flying, scurying and hoping, with no
 one knowing what to do? Where to go? 
 
 
 The caterpilars said, "Let us lok for leaves." The buterflies said, "We want
 flowers." The mice wanted holes. The squirels, birds, insects wanted tres,
 
 bushes and gras. 
 
 
 Al the animals wanted the soft earth, not cement or concrete. "Where wil
 we find al this?" they cried. "We wil surely die," they said and wept.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 7  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 8  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Kato's uncle and aunt were very quiet and al the litle 
 squirels crept close to their mom. 
 
 
 Kato cleared his throat and spoke shyly, "I live in the Far 
 
 Forest, may be we can al go there?" 
 
 There was a buz of excitement and someone said, "How?" 
 
 
 Kato scratched his head and thought hard, "Wel, the Squirel 
 
 Expres can take the squirels and the buterflies, spiders 
 caterpilars and al the insects. The birds can either fly or 
 come with us. The moles, mice and the gras snake family 
 
 can go by the underground Mole Expres." 
 
 
 
 
 
 9  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 10  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Everyone thought it was a splendid idea. 
 
 
 Mister Poples rushed to ask Mister Grumbles, the driver of
 the underground expres train if he could take them al to the
 
 Far Forest. Mister Grumbles fumbled, stumbled, bumbled
 before he finaly mumbled, "Alright." 
 
 
 Now it was Mister Poples' turn to be grand. "Friends, you
 ned not wory, my grandfather's grandson's.third nephew's
 
 second niece's family live in the Far Forest. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 So, in the early hours of the morning the 
 Squirel Expres and the Mole 
 underground train with al its pasengers, 
 
 chuged their way to the Far Forest with 
 its tres, flowers, ponds and soft earth.
